title: facebook turns 15 here social
story: NewsFacebook turns  - here are the social networks most controversial momentsMark Zuckenbergs social networking site now has more than .billion users - but has been hit by by controversy and criticism along the wayShareByMatt Roper:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsFacebook has been accused of failing to protect users privacy "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt might feel like it’s been part of our lives for ever, but Facebook only came into existence just  years ago today. The social media giant today has more than .billion users and last year its profits soared  per cent to an incredible .billion. But it has also been tarnished by a number of high-profile scandals and crises over the years, from privacy issues to accusations it helped Russia sabotage the US elections. Here are Facebook’s most controversial moments… September : Co-founder cut out  Facebook started with a controversy when Mark Zuckerberg kicked out co-founder Eduardo Saverin within months of the social network being launched in February . In late , fellow Hard undergraduates Mark and Eduardo worked together to launch The Facebook, with Brazilian Eduardo investing , in exchange for  per cent of the company. It proved incredibly popular at Harward but when Zuckerberg, along with another student, Dusty Muskovitz, moved to Palo Alto six months later to develop the company, Saverin moved to New York and worked on another start-up. Their relationship soured and in September  Zuckerberg cut Saverin out by creating a new company to acquire the old firm, then distributed shares in the start up to everybody but him.  Saverin eventually sued Facebook and he settled with a five per cent stake in the company - that is now worth close to billion. November : Beacon ads controversy Facebook launched the Beacon advertising system in , which was designed to track the activities of users on  partner websites and then report these activities to their Facebook friends, unless they specically were told not to do so. It generated a storm of privacy complaints over the tracking of user activities, with many claiming the site had adopted Big Brother tactics to make money. There were also allegations that web partners shared user information without their consent. One man, for instance, bought jewellery online for his we, who was then notied of the purchase - along with all of his other Facebook friends. The couple ended up as part of a class-action lawsuit against the site for violating federal privacy laws. The system prompted , people to sign up to an online petition entitled Facebook, stop invading my privacy!”.  After an uproar Facebook eventually let users turn Beacon off and CEO Mark Zuckerberg publicly apologised. In a blog entry Zuckerberg said: Weve made a lot of mistakes building this feature, but weve made even more with how weve handled them. We simply did a bad job with this release, and I apologise for it.  May : Canada privacy report The Canadian Internet Policy and Public Interest Clinicaccused Facebook of deceiving its users and breaking privacy laws in a complaint to Canada’s Privacy Commissioners. The group released a -page complaint detailing  separate violations of the law, including how third-party applications collect all information available about Facebook users when they’re added and can even access information about other people through the user’s friends list. At the time Canada was third in overall users on Facebook, with about seven million users. October : Apps privacy scandal An investigation by the Wall Street Journal found that  of the most popular Facebook apps - including FarmVille and Mafia wars - were being given users’ identity numbers and the ability to track names, online habits, and other personal information, regardless of privacy settings.  The newspaper found that three of the top  apps, including FarmVille, had not only transmitted users IDs to outside companies but also personal information about users’ friends. Facebook, which by now had million users, acknowledged the mistake. Both Facebook and Zynga, the company behind Farmville and other apps, were hit with lawsuits based on the privacy breaches. June : Tag Suggest scandal Facebook faced further criticism over its privacy policies in June  for quietly switching on technology that automatically identies people in photos. The Tag Suggestions system uses facial recognition software to identy iniduals as photos are uploaded, and then encourages their friends to tag them so that others can easily access the images. The feature was turned on by default, meaning members had to opt outthey didn’t want to be part of the system. It lead to an outcry from privacy campaigners, who claimed that data had been collected and processed without consent. Following an investigation by privacy authorities in Ireland and Germany Facebook was forced to switch off its facial recognition tool and delete data collected from European users in October .   February : Free Basics flop A Facebook project which was supposed to provide free internet to the world’s poorest people flopped spectacularly after it was accused of “digital colonialism”. Free Basics offered users in more than  countries a narrowed down version of the internet, in partnership with local telephone companies who agreed to reduce data charges to zero. The catch - it wasn’t real internet access, but a selection of apps and services controlled by, and always including, Facebook. The project was discontinued after the Indian government closed down Free Basics following months of protests referred to as the modern ‘Quit India’ - when Mahatma Gandhi expelled the British in . Following the decision Facebook board member Mark Andreessen tweeted sarcastically, “Anti-colonialism has been economically catastrophic for the Indian people for decades. Why stop now ”  He later tweeted: “I apologize for any offense caused by my earlier tweet about Indian history and politics. I admire India and the Indian people enormously.” May : Trending Topics claims Facebook endured some of its most sustained criticism to date after a number of publications leaked information on the internal process behind Trending Topics, the network’s column of the day’s top news stories. Former employees alleged that Facebook deliberately blacklisted certain topics and sources, boosted topics that weren’t actually trending, and intentionally suppressed conservative media. They also claimed writers who drafted the blurbs were told to change words, like renaming Twitter and Snapchat “social networks.” Facebook denied claims of bias, but said its guidelines had been claried and reviewers undergone refresher training “that emphasised content decisions may not be made on the basis of politics or ideology”.   October : Russian meddling scandal Facebook admitted that Russian groups intent on influencing the  US presidential election flooded Facebook with propaganda ads and  information. It eventually said Russian accounts bought more than , worth of ads.  In remarks made to Congress in October , Facebook said the Internet Research Agency, a shadowy Russian company linked to the Kremlin, had posted around , pieces of ides content that was shown to about million people between January  and August . Those posts were then liked, shared and followed by others, spreading the messages to tens of millions more people. Widespread criticism over the issue eventually made Zuckerberg take responsibility, posting: I started Facebook, and at the end of the day, I’m responsible for what happens on our . “I’m serious about doing what it takes to protect our community, Facebook has a “responsibility” to protect its user’s data andit fails, “we don’t deserve to serve you.” March : Cambridge Analytica scandal It was revealed that Facebook had inadvertently allowed political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica to gather data from million users, which was then reportedly used to influence the  presidential election. The information was gathered through an app that paid users to take a personality test but that also harvested details about their Facebook friends. It was then shared with Cambridge Analytica, which worked for Donald Trumps campaign team in the  US presidential election and used the data to build a software programme to target political advertising in the US.  In October last year Facebook was fined pound, by the UK’s Information Commissioners Officeover the data scandal, saying the social network “contravened the law by failing to safeguard people’s information.” March : Myanmar claims In the latest in a series of criticisms about the proleration of fake news, Facebook was blamed for enabling the spread of fake news in Myanmar about Rohingya Muslims, who are being systematically slaughtered. The social media giant admitted it failed to prevent its  from being used to “foment ision and inside offline violence” in the country, and vowed to invest resources in addressing the abuse of the network in the country. It isn’t the only country where Facebook has been accused of inciting violence. Following anti-Muslim violence in Sri Lanka, the country ordered internet providers and mobile phone carriers to shut down both Facebook and WhatsApp, while government officials in Papua New Guinea considered the same. March : Maybe someone dies scandal BuzzFeed News published an internal memo from Facebook executive Andrew Bosworth in which one of Zuckerberg’s most trusted lieutenants calls any effort to connect the world a “de facto good. He had written in June : “Maybe it costs a le by exposing someone to bullies. Maybe someone dies in a terrorist attack coordinated on our tools... And still we connect people.” The note caused a backlash externally in light of troubling events, including Facebook’s role in abetting genocide in Myanmar and its role in broadcasting a spate of suicides and murders on its livestreaming tool. In a statement, Zuckerberg disputed the idea that Bosworth was speaking for the company and said: “Weve never believed the ends justy the means.” Bosworth tweeted - and later deleted: “I don’t agree with the post today and I didn’t agree with it even when I wrote it.” September : Biggest ever data breach  Facebook disclosed that it had been hit by its worst ever data breach, affecting million users - including those of Zuckerberg and COO Sheryl Sandberg. Attackers exploited the sites View As feature, which lets people see what their profiles look like to other users. The unknown attackers took advantage of a feature in the code called Access Tokens, to take over peoples accounts, potentially giving hackers access to private messages, photos and posts, and also tried to harvest peoples private information, including name, sex and hometown, from Facebooks systems.

title: alien metal brought earth meteor
story: NewsAlien metal brought to Earth on the meteor that wiped out dinosaurs could cure cancerKnown as iridium it penetrates the nucleus of cancer cells by latching onto tumour cells - but is harmless to healthy onesShareCommentsByMark Waghorn:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe huge meteor which is said to have wiped out the dinosaurs "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn alien metal brought to Earth on the meteor that wiped out the dinosaurs could cure cancer, according to new research. Known as iridium, its the worlds rarest element. Blasting it with a laser beam produces a poisonous form of oxygen that is deadly for tumour cells - and harmless for healthy ones. Experiments showed it penetrates the nucleus of cancer cells by latching onto the blood protein albumin. It could revolutionise treatment for the deadliest forms of the disease, say British scientists. It becomes toxic only when exposed to light - an existing treatment known as photodynamic therapy.   This activates the metal to kill them through oxidisation - where the cells own oxygen is converted into a lethal form. Vitally, healthy tissue is unaffected.Professor Peter Sadler, from the department of chemistry at Warwick University, said:Its amazing this large protein can penetrate into cancer cells and deliver iridium which can kill them selectively on activation with visible light.If this technology can be translated into the clinic it might be effective against resistant cancers and reduce the side effects of chemotherapy. He said it can be applied locally - and in smaller doses. The next step is pre-clinical animal trials. His international team used a special organic coating to hook up iridium to albumin - which then glowed very brightly.   Under powerful microscopes they tracked its passage into lung cancer tumours grown in the lab - and found it destroyed them. Photodynamic therapy is based on chemical compounds called photosensitizers that produce oxidising species when switched on by lasers. Its already being used to treat a range of common cancers including those of the skin, breast and lung. When photosensitisers are exposed to a specic wave of light they produce a form of oxygen that kills nearby cells. Clinicians can target them to specically attack cancer cells using thin, flexible tubes called optical fibres that carry light signals.  The study published in Angewandte Chemie International Edition found the iridium based compound is an excellent photosensitiser. What is more albumin was able to deliver it right into the nucleus of cancer cells - which contains all the genetic material. The dormant iridium can then be turned on by red laser light irradiation - destroying them from their very centre. The bright luminescence of the iridium allowed its accumulation in the nucleus of tumours - and its activation leading to the death of cells - to be followed in real time.  Co-author Dr Cinzia Imberti, also from Warwick, said: Its fascinating how albumin can deliver our photosensitiser so specically to the nucleus. We are at a very early stage, but we are looking forward to see where the pre-clinical development of this new compound can lead. The idea is when light is shone onto tumours through the skin the compound will effectively kill tumours - leaving healthy cells untouched. With cancer becoming resistant to certain treatments its crucial to find other methods such as this.  The compound damages proteins that manage heat shock stress and glucose metabolism - crucial molecules for cancers survival. Dr Imberti said: Our team is not only extremely multidisciplinary, including biologists, chemists and pharmacists, but also highly international, including young researchers from China, India and Italy supported by Royal Society Newton and Sir Henry Wellcome Fellowships. Iridium landed in the Gulf of Mexico  million years ago on the massive seven mile wide space rock that killed off  percent of living species - including the dinosaurs. Laser-based techniques are emerging as viable treatments for cancer - targeting tumours far more precisely than the shotgun blast of radiation and chemotherapy. The brittle silvery-white metal has no effect on non-cancerous tissue - indicating its a highly targeted treatment that doesnt attack healthy cells. Its found in the world famous Chicxulub crater underneath the Yucatan Peninsula caused by the asteroid strike believed responsible for the death of the dinosaurs. The precious metal platinum is already used in over half of cancer chemo-therapies. Prof Sadler believes other precious metals like iridium - that are safe with minimum side-effects - can potentially combat resistance. He says: Its certainly now time to try to make good medical use of the iridium delivered to us by an asteroid  million years ago.

The Ryanair flight bound for Madrid when it was caught in a snowstorm at the Vaclav Havel Airport in the Czech Republic capital Prague. The incident took place at the when the FR flight to Madrid was grounded at around am on Sunday, February . Reports said the snowstorm continually worsened and there was no food or water available to offer passengers.   One Ryanair customer wrote on Twitter that several passengers suffered anxiety attacks on the packed plane, while parents struggled with their young ones. Reports said that the passengers were eventually allowed off the plane after six hours and ventured out into the snow and howling winds. A spokesperson of Menzies Aviation, which provides services for Ryanair at the Prague airport, told local media that “the passengers will spend the night in the airport hotel”. A Ryanair spokesman said: Snow at Prague airport and slow airport de-icing services caused a number of delays yesterday and this flight to Madrid was regrettably cancelled, as the crew went out of hours.All customers were provided with hotel accommodation and boarded a replacement flight, which departed to Madrid earlier today.We sincerely apologised to all affected customers”

title: woman secretly lives man accused
story: NewsWoman lives with man accused of brutally murdering her dad  years agoVince Zangari was once charged with the brutal murder of Salvatore Sam Rotiroti - who was beaten to death in his driveway in Melbourne in ShareByAbigail OLeary:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsPictured left to right: Salvatore, his we Giuseppina and their five children Maria, Tony, Elizabeth, Joe and Vince"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman is said to be living with a man accused of murdering her dad  years ago. Maria Rotiroti has reportedly been living with Vince Zangari in her northern Sydney home in Australia for the last eight years. He remains a suspect in the cold case murder of her father Salvatore Sam Rotiroti, according to police - who call Zangari a person of interest. Rotiroti was beaten to death in his driveway in Geelong, Melbourne, in September  - when Maria was just  years old. While Vince Zangari was charged for the murder, the case against him was dropped and there is no reason to believe he carried out the brutal killing. Despite this, Marias brother Vince Rotiroti said his father would come out of his gravehe knew about the living arrangement, reports the Mail. He told The Herald Sun : Its shocking that she is living with the man police suspect of committing the murder.   Maria and Vinces father Sam Rotiroti worked a concreter, and shortly before his death had paid a , ransom to have his kidnapped son Tony freed. The unknown kidnapper had tried extorting more money from Rotiroti before he was found dead on his driveway. During their investigation, police swooped on then -year-old Vince Zangari, who was charged. However, the case charge was dropped when witnesses began withdrawing or changing their statements. Now living under the name of Luke Conrad, Zangari, and Maria Rotiroti also jointly owned a property in Double Bay, an affluent harbourside suburb in Sydney.   They were both declared bankrupt in . Last year, a million reward for information on the cold case murder which would lead to a conviction was offered by homicide detectives. title: dundee united loan signing charlie seaman wants to return to bournemouth with medal
story: Dundee United loan signing Charlie Seaman has come to Dundee United to develop as a player and get first-team experience.And he also aims to be heading back to parent club Bournemouth this summer with a Scottish Championship medal in his pocket.In capturing the -year-old full-back from one of the surprise success stories of the English Premier League over the past few seasons, Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson stressed the deal was exactly what it said on the tin – a loan.The end of the season will see Seaman head back to the south coast and be expected to challenge for a top-team place with the Cherries.However, while his time in Scotland will be a learning experience, the former West Ham youth wants success as well.“Hopefully, coming here and learning dferent things will help me for when I go back for next season,” he said.“I can learn dferent styles here so I am really happy to be in Scotland with United.“The boys here love to play football and that’s good because it’s that way down at Bournemouth.“Every side of the game, though, on the ball, off the ball I am trying to learn, it’s what I’m here for. Defensively I am trying to be better and I want to be better offensively as well.“I came here to get experience of first-team football. I was waiting for my chance at Bournemouth but I felt I could get it here sooner, get some games for the rest of the season. Hopefully I will be more readyI get the opportunity when I go back, or wherever it may be.“There is a job to do for the team as well and our goal at Dundee United is to win this league. Yes, it would be nice to be finishing the season with a medal for that.”Seaman’s time north of the border hardly got off to the perfect start and, within hours of his arrival, he was tasting defeat as United went down to Ayr.His temporary manager was disappointed with the team performance at Somerset Park but did make a point of saying the new arrival had put in some good work.The young full-back took encouragement from that but has admitted he did not necessarily agree with Robbie’s assessment.“I was happy to make my debut last week, obviously disappointed with the loss, but it was good to get out there and experience something dferent,” he added.“I didn’t think I started the game too well but I thought I grew into it. Still, personally, I don’t think it was one of my better games by any stretch.“It was my first game at the club, my first playing a dferent style of football and my first playing in dferent weather conditions and stuff like that.“It was all a learning curve, something to take from that game into future games.“I came up Thursday night, so I only had a day here before the game but I have high expectations and I like to set high standards.“When I don’t reach them, I’m disappointed.”The aim now is to show up well as he makes his home debut as Morton visit Tannadice and United try to get back to winning ways to keep in touch with leaders Ross County.And Seaman does admit this week has given him more time to do his homework on the opposition, saying: “Before Ayr the gaffer gave me a lot of clips of Ayr to watch so I had a fair idea of what they were going to do.“I was relatively ready for the game in a tactical aspect but I did only come up on Thursday night.“For this game against Morton we have been getting information throughout the week. So I’ve an idea of what to expect and I am looking forward to playing in front of our own fans.”

title: dundee uniteds nicky clark says we are making life very hard for ourselves
story: Nicky Clark admits Dundee United are “making it very hard for ourselves” as their bid for promotion to the Premiership stumbles yet again.The Tangerines fell six points behind leaders Ross County and three behind Ayr United after losing to the Honest Men - last Friday.With  matches remaining in the Championship race, Clark admits the Tangerines need to pick up three points more often than not between now and the end of the campaign.And that starts this weekend at home to Greenock Morton.The striker said: “We’re still up there, still round about it but we know we need to pick up now.“The next game is massive for us now, we need three points because we are making it really hard for ourselves but we need to just concentrate on our own matches and it’s important we pick up three points from most games between now and the end of the season.“There is still plenty of time, especially in this league because everybody seems to beat everybody, but it’s games like Friday you need to go and winyou want to win titles.“Friday we didn’t manage that so we only have ourselves to blame.“However, we have Morton this weekend and we can galvanise ourselves and get three points.“Saturday will be tough – it’s all good teams in this league so we need to prepare ourselves this week. The gaffer will get us ready for it and we need to make sure we go and do the business.”The performance at Somerset Park was a bitter disappointment for the  United fans who made the long trip on a Friday night.And Clark admits it wasn’t good enough from the Tangerines.He added: “We went down to Ayr with full intentions of winning the game.“We gave ourselves a chance a couple of weeks ago against Dunfermline when we won and got ourselves up the league but we let ourselves and the fans down on Friday.“The weather meant it was never going to be a pretty game and they got a chance early on and took it.“I think we only had one real chance with Aidan towards the end where the goalie was out quick and made a good save.“All in all it was a very frustrating night and we were very disappointed.”Strong winds made le dficult for all the players but it was clear Ian McCall’s men coped far better with the conditions than United.The home side dominated the opening period and got their goal through Craig Moore early on but the expected response from the Tangerines with the wind in their favour in the second half never really materialised.Clark added: “It was dficult conditions but we’ve all played in wind like that before, we all know what it’s like.“We had a game plan – I don’t knowwe didn’t stick to it but it never happened for us.“We’re disappointed because that’s nine points we’ve given Ayr this season and we’re making it very hard for ourselves.”It’s been a stop-start first season at the club for Clark with a series of injuries curtailing his first-team opportunities.Now, though, he says he’s back to % and ready to help United get back on track.“It’s been very frustrating for me, I’ve missed a lot of games with daft wee injuries here and there where you can’t actually treat them, you just have to leave them until they get better.“It’s been frustrating but I’m back and feeling good now so, hopefully, I can kick on now and help the team get where we want to be.”

title: former dundee united man one of two new arrivals at dundee
story: Dundee have completed a double transfer swoop today.The club have secured the loan signings of former Dundee United defender Ryan McGowan and Sunderland midfielder Ethan Robson on loan until the end of the season.The -year-old Australia international McGowan joins up from Bradford City and had a previous spell across Tannadice Street at United in  .He has played at both right-back and centre-half throughout his senior career, which started at Hearts, but is also adept in central midfield.Midfielder Robson moves north to Dens Park from Jack Ross’ Sunderland.The -year-old has found first-team opportunities limited at the Black Cats this season and will instead try to help the Dee stave off the threat of relegation.

title: queen of the south boss gary naysmith surprised to sign fraser aird from dundee united
story: Dundee United midfielder Fraser Aird has joined fellow Championship side Queen of the South.Aird was a key player for United earlier in the season, contributing three goals and  assists in  games, but has fallen out of favour since Robbie Neilson took the reins.The -year-old Canadian has gone to Dumfries on loan until the end of the season.Queen of the South boss Gary Naysmith said: “I am delighted and also a little surprised that we have managed to bring Fraser to the club.#With Dundee United changing their manager recently and Robbie wanting to bring in his own players, Fraser has found himself on the outside looking in in recent weeks and once we thought we had a chance of getting him we moved quickly to add him to the squad.#He is only  and is a current Canadian international, who was in outstanding form for Dundee United earlier in the season.#He has three goals and twelve assists from  games this season and is someone who will add another dimension to our attacking threat.#Fraser is comfortable playing on either wing, he has a lot of experience for someone his age having played over  games for Rangers, Vancouver, Dunfermline, Falkirk and Dundee United as well as having eight caps for Canada.#

title: union members vote 98 in favour of strike ballot for angus council staff
story: Union members have voted % in favour of a strike ballot for staff at Angus Council.Unite the union has today confirmed that members at Angus Council have moved a step closer to industrial action after members voted overwhelmingly in favour of holding a legal ballot.The move is in response to Angus Council imposing changes to the terms and conditions of  staff who work in environmental services.From April , household waste will be collected from am until pm which will mean that workers will be required to move to a day sht back sht work pattern.Unite members have raised concerns about the dangers of operating the service safely and effectively, and the negative impact that these changes will have on work-le balance.Dougie Maguire, Unite regional co-ordinating officer, said: “The resounding vote in favour of moving towards an industrial action ballot at Angus Council should come as no surprise.#Unite members are furious at the proposed changes to sht patterns and working hours, which we believe will lead to a poorer service.#Unite will now hold a ballot to defend our members’ terms and conditions.#This result should focus the minds of Angus Council or they will face imminent industrial action.”An Angus Council spokesman said: “Changes are being introduced to deliver essential savings and allow us to do so without a reduction in jobs or in our kerbside collection service to households.“Through this process, we have consulted with other councils operating similar sht systems and carefully considered all operational and safety issues to ensure any such issues are addressed.#Trade unions and staff have been consulted throughout the development of these proposals.“We are aware of the outcome of the consultative ballot carried out by Unite.#Our officers are meeting with Unite this week as part of continuing discussions.”

title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Clachnacuddin FC pays tribute to superfan from Yorkshire
story: Bronwyn Wain , who lived in Huddersfield, was described as a ldquolovely lady and ldquoreal character by club figures.Despite living in Yorkshire, her unlikely association with the club began in  when she got in touch with the Lilywhites out of curiosity about the clubrsquos name and history.The links grew from there and she became a true Lily when she visited Grant Street as club guest in . Her husband John, who passed away a few months ago, joined her.ldquoThey were a lovely couple. Just ordinary folk who took the club to their hearts and they became well-known to many of our players, directors and fans, said Billy Corbett, a former director of the club. ldquoIt was the name Clachnacuddin that attracted her attention. Its a Gaelic word and means lsquothe stone of the tubrsquo. But when she got in touch we responded by sending her a hat and scarf and some programmes.ldquoShe was absolutely thrilled and kept in touch through Facebook checking results and encouraging the team. She sent money every month to one of our fans to buy her ticket in the Lily Lotto. She had so many friends the club had a whip round for her and her husband to visit.During the trip they attended a Clach game against Strathspey Thistle , which the Lilywhites won - ndash a result which left the couple ldquotickled pink. Former director Jim Oliver also showed them round town and on a cruise down Loch Ness.ldquoI donrsquot think they had ever been to Scotland but they got a real taste of Highland League hospitality, Mr Corbett added.Following her death the couplersquos son Michael passed on his heartfelt thanks to Clach fans and officials for all they had done for his parents.Jim Oliver said: ldquoA lovely lady whom the Clach Facebook followers got to know very well. All in all she was a real character.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: DJ marathon charity event in Inverness aims to be a money spinner
story: Several local DJs will take to the decks during the Caledonian V Cancer event this Saturday in aid of CLIC Sargent.The music starts at pm and finishes at am on Sunday, and the sound selectors will include DJs Terry Fire, Lady Beats, Andy Innis, CKaz and Richard Lewis.The event has been organised in memory of Michael Murphy who succumbed to cancer last year aged .Michaelrsquos uncle Sean , of Dalneigh, is a regular in the bar.Sean has already organised several fundraising events across Inverness, and so far he has raised more than pound for the charity.Sean said he was really grateful to the Caledonian and all the DJs for their support, adding: ldquoMichael first became unwell in  and he had two forms of leukaemia and sadly died last September.ldquoCLIC Sargent really helped us through some hard times so I became involved in the fundraising.Michael was involved in last yearrsquos Stand Up To Cancer campaign on Channel  having been filmed for the national fundraiser prior to his death.The former factory worker and McDonaldrsquos crew member lived in Forres before moving to Inverness.Mark Glendinning, general manager of the Caledonian, said: ldquoWe try to support as many local events as possible, but this one is particularly special as Sean is both a friend and regular customer.ldquoCLIC Sargent is a wonderful charity that supports cancer patients and their families during incredibly dficult times.ldquoThey were particularly helpful to Michaelrsquos we Shannon and young daughter Sophia after he passed away, so we want to help Sean raise funds for them to give something back.CLIC Sargent supports children and young people with cancer and leukaemia and the Caledonian event will be held ahead of World Cancer Day on Monday.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland air traffic controllers to be balloted over strike action
story: The Prospect Union has already notied Highlands and Islands Airports Ltdthat it will be asking air traffic controllers to cast a vote regarding a strike. An indicative ballot in October gained overwhelming support.The dispute centres on the controllers at Inverness and where being paid much less than their counterparts further south, which the union maintains is unfair.An innovative centralised air traffic control system that many fear could lead to job losses in years to come has also added to the bitterness in the dispute, though it is not part of the current move.Before Christmas both Prospect and HIAL agreed to an evidence-based business case that set out the pay gap between HIAL and the rest of the industry in an attempt to resolve the dispute.Prospect believesHIAL cannot attract and retain controllers through pay issues, this has and will continue to cause staff shortages and pose a risk to maintaining service provision.According to the union it has no choice but to move towards industrial action after Scottish Ministers rejected the business case earlier this week without explanation and with no additional funding offered.Prospect negotiation officer David Avery said: ldquoScottish Ministers have been promising pay restoration for public sector workers but their policy fails to deliver.ldquoThere is a global shortage of air traffic controllers which is driving wages up across the industry - at the same time HIAL staff have received below inflation pay awards.ldquoIt is unfair that a HIAL air traffic controller, providing an essential service for the Highlands and Islands, is being paid half as much their counterpart in London ndash enough is enough.ldquoOur members have tried every other means to resolve this dispute but by rejecting a fair and reasonable proposal to resolve the dispute ministers have left them with no option but to pursue strike action.HIAL HR director Andrea Sillars, said: ldquoHIAL note the position taken by the Ministers. We are disappointed that Prospect have decided to ballot their members on strike action. We remain committed to continuing constructive discussions to help resolve the dispute and are open to holding further talks with Prospect on a recruitment and retention allowance for Air Traffic Control staff. We await the outcome of the ballot.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Intake cap at seven Inverness schools
story: SEVEN Inverness schools will have their rolls capped in - academic session.The move was triggered by high demand for places at each school.The primary schools affected by the cap are Holm, Lochardil, Kinmylies and Milton of Leys while three secondary schools ndash Charleston, Culloden and Millburn Academies ndash will also have the first year intake limited.The local authority said it will do its best to accommodate all pupils in their preferred choice of school but warned that they would be subject to criteria.Pupils must be within the Highland area and within the geographical catchment of the school concerned or  certied medical reasons or additional support needs best be served by a specic school are needed.If pupils had siblings at a particular school that would also help their case while religious belief for denominational schools would also be a factor.Educational courses unavailable at one school or pupils living within the catchment area of a secondary school that is not subject to capping might impact where a child can go as would proximity to home to school and road safety or ease of travel.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Site for Inverness homes not acceptable
story: Councillor Ken Gowans hit out at the application by agent Bracewell-Stirling for DMPM Services.He said the site was not zoned for housing and would pile pressure on local school rolls which are already well over  per cent capacity.ldquoWhile we need more affordable houses, any development must be part of the local plan, and this development is not.ldquoThis is likely to generate more unacceptable pressures on infrastructure which is already struggling to cope at the moment.ldquoWhile developers pay contributions towards education, it doesnrsquot change the fact that local schools are beyond full, and the councilrsquos school roll projections indicate these will worsen in the short to medium term, he said.Highlands MSP and road safety campaigner David Stewart also expressed some concern: ldquoI am mindful that the dual A will be at one side of this site and the rural B road will extend along another side of the site.ldquoAs it stands, this particular road has no pavement for pedestrians and this would be an issue that would cause me concern.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: aberdeen community calls for new link road
story: A community council has called on Aberdeen City Council bosses to look at the possibility of introducing a new link road.Cults, Bieldside and Milltimber Community Council has raised concerns over the amount of traffic using Westerton Road and Pitfodels Station Road, east of Cults.Westerton Road is currently closed due to work taking place in the area. A community council spokesman said traffic in the area has been problematic and wants Aberdeen City Council to explore long-term alternative options.He said: “For the longer term we don’t believe that Westerton Road or Pitfodels Station Road are viable as through routes given today’s traffic.“We would much prefer to see a modern well-engineered link road between North Deeside Road and Inchgarth Road on the open ground to the West of Pitfodels Station Road.“Aberdeen City Council is aware of our views.”

title: mothballed aberdeen community council could be rising again
story: An application has been lodged to reform a mothballed Aberdeen community council.Northfield Community Council was forced to close last year after a lack of volunteers to serve as members.Eight people were needed to continue.At the time, community councillors pledged the group would .Residents had to wait until January  to apply for re-establishment and an application has been submitted to Aberdeen City Council.A council spokeswoman said: “We can confirm that we have received an application to request that Northfield Community Council is re-established.“The application will now be checked and validated before a date for an election is set.“Once a date has been set, residents interested in being on the community council will need to complete a nomination form and follow the usual election process.”Councillor Ciaran McRae, who represents Northfield, pledged his support for the community council should it reopen.He said: “It’s great to see the community council coming forward and applying for reestablishment.“It was a great loss to the area that they were no longer there.“It’s great that they’re trying to get back up and running again.“I really hope that people will come forward and get involved for the betterment of the community.”Councillor Gordon Graham added: “I look forward to them being re-established. I was disappointed when they didn’t get the numbers the first time.”If the application is granted, an election will then be held to determine membership.

title: plans lodged for wedding marquee at north east mansion
story: The Queen’s cousin has lodged plans to erect a marquee all summer to host weddings next to a historic house.David Carnegie, the Duke of Fe, has submitted the planning application to Aberdeenshire Council seeking permission to erect the structure at Elsick House near Newtonhill during the warmer months.Caroline, the Duchess of Fe told the Evening Express the couple want to be able to erect the marquee for the duration of the summer, rather than re-erecting it for each event. It would be in use between April and September.According to planning documents, it would sit outside the main Elsick House and measure  metres by  metres.The duchess said: “More than three years ago we opened Elsick House as an exclusive use and corporate venue.“We wanted this secluded spot to be enjoyed by many for their special events, making the most of the close proximity to the city centre yet , acres of surrounding idyllic countryside.“Set in a walled garden overlooking lawns and flowerbeds, the marquee has become extremely popular on a single-use basis.“With more than  weddings booked for this year we feel that it is sensible for us to have the marquee situated permanently for the summer months, rather than erecting it for each occasion.”A noise impact assessment submitted to the local authority by developers said there would be no adverse impact on neighbouring properties outside the estate.The document said: “It is understood that events held within the marquee will typically take place until .am, typically on any days between Monday and Saturday, from April to October.“It was agreed with Aberdeenshire Council that music noise arising within residential properties due to the operation of the marquee should be no more than dBA .”Elsick House is a historic house in Kincardineshire, which has been in the hands of the Bannerman family since .Members of the public have until February  to submit their views to Aberdeenshire Council over the application.The duke and duchess were the driving force behind the creation of the new town of Chapelton at Elsick. When complete it will have , houses.The first residents moved into Chapelton in February  and it is now home to about  people with some  properties occupied.

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: bob shields national trust who
story: NewsBob Shields: National Trust owe an apology over asking people for donations to restore Burns CottageShareByGary Fanning:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsBurns Cottage needs restoration"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI’m trying to imagine the back-slapping and glad-handing at the National Trust For Scotland’s Hermiston Quay headquarters when someone came up with a spfing ‘Save Burns Cottage’ wheeze. “Let’s send out a begging letter to all those with Burns Cottage closest to their hearts – the people of Ayr . . .” “Wonderful idea!” “We could arrange for it to land on their doorsteps on Burns birthday – January  . . .” “That’s genius!” “Throw in some pictures of cracked walls and the dodgy thatched roof . . . “ “Fantastic!” “Use phrases like “before it’s too late” – or “damaged beyond repair” . . . “It’s heartbreaking!” “That’s Burns Cottage sorted then! Gin and tonic anyone ” “Large ones all round!” To be serious though – I still can’t decide what made me angrier. The crass begging bowl letter – hoping to cash in on the biggest Burns day of the year  Or the fact that Burns Cottage has been allowed to fall into such a state that phrases like “damaged beyond repair” are even necessary  If we’re talking man’s insensitivity to man here – then last Friday’s NTS letter takes the bannock! Its contents have upset dozens of people I know – and judging by the reaction on social media, hundreds more that I don’t know. Nicky Cotter wrote: “NTS . . . put your hands in your pockets and get it fixed. If you can spend pound, on a wooden tree house at Culzean Castle – you can stump up pound, to fix one of the most historically and culturally signicant buildings in Scotland”. Spot on, sir. The NTS letter tells us that “time and Scotland’s wet winters have taken their toll”. Yes – that’ll be the  winters since Burns father William Burness built the cottage on . And during that period, it’s been thatched more times than Wayne Rooney’s balding napper. If the current thatch “has signicant tears and has worn away”, you have to askthe last thatching work was in some way inferior - orthe cottage needed re-thatched several years ago and the work was never undertaken  You then start wondering how the auld clay biggin’ managed to survive the  wet Scottish winters between the cottage being built and the National Trust for Scotland’s formation back in   The answer is fairly obvious. Back then – people looked after it! And you only have to look at the recent row over the deteriorating Burns Monument to start wonderingthe NTS is the right custodian of our Burns heritage  Burns Cottage is everything Mr Cotter said earlier . .. and more. It’s the most important building in Ayrshire – by a lang Scots mile. Every nook, cranny - and twig of its roof - should be the subject of a fingertip, annual inspection. And whatever work is required – at whatever cost – should be sanctioned immediately. In fact, I imagine that’s what ‘most people’ thought was already happening. But then we had last Friday’s mail . . . when ‘most people’ discovered to their horror that the north-west gable is starting to pull away from the rest of the cottage! If admission fees don’t cover the cost of Burns Cottage – then put them up! The last figures I have show , visitors in . Charging them an extra p would have reached the pound, required – with enough left over to putty the windows as well. So, I’m sorry, NTS. But this was the wrong letter . . . to the wrong people . . . on the wrong day. You owe a lot of honest men and a lot of bonnie lassies an apology!Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr

title: brave mcdonalds worker hailed hero
story: NewsBrave McDonalds worker hailed a hero after rescuing a gran from fireLewis Macdonald, , battled back flames and thick smoke to save the le of Nan MarshallShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsLewis saved the le of Nan Marshall. "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave McDonald’s worker has been hailed a hero after rescuing a gran from a burning home. Lewis Macdonald, , battled flames and thick smoke to save the le of granny-of-three Nan Marshall from a blaze which broke out in her living room. The sht manager was driving past -year-old Nan’s home on Castlehill Road in the early hours of New Year’s Eve when he saw flames flickering in the window. A Las Vegas neon sign – which Nan popped on for the festivities – had caught alight. Quick-thinking Lewis, along with pal Lauren Kennedy, sounded the alarm, got Nan to safety and dampened the fire with towels before the fire brigade arrived at the scene.Lewis told the Ayrshire Post : “The whole night was a blur.“We were driving back from work and I saw a fire in the window. “I was chapping on the door and ringing the doorbell. “The full house was covered in black smoke. “I couldn’t see anything. “I didn’t know how long the firemen were going to take and the house was still on fire so I thought I needed to do something. “Nan was shook up about it. “I was trying to get into the kitchen because Nan said there were towels at the washing machine. “They were pretty damp so I just threw them over it. “After we put the fire out, we sat on the wall and waited for thefiremen. They had a big extractor fan and they were trying to get all the smoke out.“It had even got upstairs, the firefighters said.” Nan was upstairs sleeping at the time unaware as to what was going on. She said: “I wondered what it was. “I could hear the doorbell and by this time the smoke alarm kicked in. “Luckily I woke and came down the stairs and there was my hero at the door. “Buthe hadn’t of been here I would’ve been a goner with the smoke alone. “Even now, anything you touch you’re covered in black soot. “I was in a state of shock. “The table caught fire and the windowsill. “I had to go to the doctor two or three days later because I kept wheezing.” Daughter Lesley Watson, , added: “It could’ve been so much worse –Lewis just caught it in time. “If that young man hadn’t been passing, she wouldn’t be here today.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyr

title: driver who sped 70mph through
story: NewsDriver who sped at mph through streets of Troon is jailed for  monthsMark Kirkby almost killed his passenger when he finally crashed into a wall following the high speed chase.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsMark Kirkby was jailed for the reckless driving"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who drove like a maniac through the streets of Troon has been jailed for  months, writes Edwin Lawrence. Mark Kirkby, , almost killed passenger Kerrie Anne Monaghan when he finally crashed into a wall. Miss Monaghan was in Ayr Sherf Court on crutches to hear the sentence on her partner, who she is standing by. The court heard Kirkby did not even have a driving licence and Sherf John Montgomery banned him from holding one for four years. Depute fiscal Lindsay Bain told the court police spotted a silver Volvo being driven erratically from Barassie Street into Portland Street. The police car’s blue lights went on and Kirkby initially slowed down before increasing speed. He was hitting mph in Templehill before heading into Harbour Road. And Kirkby’s car was said to have taken off as he drove across a mini roundabout into Port Ranald Drive. He hit mph in North Shore Road, eventually crashing into a wall at the Beach Road Kilmarnock Road junction in Barassie. During the whole episode, which began around .am on October  last year, Kirkby drove dangerously through junctions and swerved round corners.  When the crash occurred the car’s airbags were deployed but this did not prevent Ms Monaghan’s horric injuries. She had to be cut out of the car by firefighters and suffered numerous fractures to her face, head, body and limbs. “Kerrie Anne Monaghan is very lucky to be alive,” said fiscal Ms Bain. The court also heard of offences committed by Kirkbywhose address was given as Barlinnie Prison, on June . This time he was in a grey Ford Mondeo around .am when police spotted the car stationary on the A near the Pennyburn Roundabout. Kirkby was unsteady on his feet and slurring his speech, although a breath test proved negative. A a blood test found substances identied as cocaine and benzocaine. Defence lawyer Hugh Duncan said Kirkby’s relationship with Ms Monaghan was still ongoing. “He accepts full responsibility,” said the lawyer. “He comes across as remorseful to the injuries his partner suffered and to potential harm he could have done to others.” Mr Duncan said Kirkby had been remanded in custody since October , had undergone a detox programme, and had come to a realisation of his mental health issues. Sherf John Montgomery told Kirkby: “You drove dangerously at high speed for an extended period. I see no option but a custodial sentence.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnHMP BarlinnieVolvoAyrCourtsJusticeTroon

story: NewsElliots in Prestwick to "evolve" with rebrand as Vics  The VineBosses at Buzzworks say the bar and restaurant must "evolve" as part of its transformation.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB NewsBuzzworks managing director, Kenny Blair, is promising bold changes at Elliots "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Ayrshire’s biggest hospitality venues has closed for a “complete transformation”. Elliots in Prestwick will be given a new brand and feature live sport and entertainment seven days a week. The bar and restaurant shut its doors on Sunday, with bosses planning to reopen at Easter as Vic’s  The Vine. Buzzworks, who have operated Elliots as their flagship in the town, say the rebrand will be split into two halves. The bar will be called Vic’s and will be a “modern take on a traditional bar”, featuring sport and entertainment. Weekend opening hours will remain at .am.  Designer Jim Hamilton is leading the project, which will include a new glass roof in part of the bar. A new kitchen boasting a churrasco BBQ pit is also planned. Bosses say Vic’s will be the first venue in Ayrshire to serve fresh, unpasteurised tank beer straight from the brewery. Kenny added: “We’ve seen an appetite in the industry for more cool and modern pubs and, similarly to our T-Bar in Ayr, Vic’s will be a traditional bar with a twist. “This will both suit the local market and sit alongside our excellent new restaurant offering in Prestwick. “Our vision is to create the best day-to-night venue in Scotland and we are confident Vic’s  The Vine will match those expectations.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrPrestwickAyr News

story: NewsWoman wielded air rle and metal pole during rammy at Ayrshire houseThe -year-old admitted shoving the barrel of the rle into the home.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAyr Sherf Court "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA weapon wielding woman terried homeowners as she smashed windows during a violent air rle spree. Danielle Smith, , used a metal pole to shatter windows of a home on Ness Glen Road, Dalmellington on November , . But she didn’t act alone as Smith was spotted alongside a male when the pair terried their targets inside. Ayr Sherf Court heard he appeared to be carrying a black air rle. But Smith, of Castle Croft, Dalmellington, admitted shoving the barrel of the rle into the home. And the victims inside cowered in fear as they could hear Smith shouting “Get out here, get our here.” CCTV footage captured the pair on their threatening violent spree. The lawyer commented: “It’s quite clear that she was quite literally in his stead and following him. “She cannot provide the court any reasonable explanation of how she managed to get herself in this situation but she was using and abusing drink and illegal substances. “At the time she would have followed this man where-ever he went. “If you fly with the crows, you get shot with them. Mr Maxwell said that Smith has “managed to turn her le around”. He added: “The young woman who appears before you is a very dferent woman. “She understands the seriousness of this.” Sherf Scott Pattison told Smith: “My first thought was to send you to jail for this shameful behaviour and very serious nature. “However I’m going to draw back from that because of your current progress in the community payback order. “I’m told by the social work department that you’re doing well. “You’re currently free from substance and alcohol misuse which is the big thing. “Butyou transgress, you’ll go straight to jail and it’ll be for a signicant period.” Smith admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner and, whilst acting with another, shouted, did kick and strike the door with a metal pole, point the barrel of an air rle into the home and smash windows.
