title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeMonday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: airports chairwoman is appointed
story: IT HAS been announced by Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity, Michael Matheson MSP, that Lorna Jack had been appointed as chairwoman of the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited , operators of several airports, including Kirkwall Airport.Ms Jack is a chartered accountant and a graduate of Aberdeen University. She joined the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited as a non-executive director in March  and chaired its Audit Committee for over three years, until she was invited to take on the interim chair role in October .Ms Jack remains the chief executive of the Law Society of Scotland and is an independent member of the Court of University of Aberdeen and a member of its Governance and Nominations Committee. She is also a trustee and treasurer of the McConnell International Foundation.The appointment is regulated by the Commissioner for Ethical Standards in Public Le in Scotland.• Highlands and Islands Airports Limitedis a public body wholly owned by Scottish Ministers. title: christmas tree collection reminder
story: Orkney Islands Council is reminding folk that their Christmas tree collection service for households on the Orkney mainland, within mph areas only, will get underway from Monday next week.The limited collection for real trees will be carried between Monday and the following Friday, February .The intention is that trees collected will be recycled at the council’s Bossack waste facility, along with other garden waste left at recycling centres around Orkney, to produce a fine soil conditioner.Therefore anyone using the tree collection service is urged to take extra care that all tinsel and decorations are removed from their trees.The soil conditioner can be picked up free of charge, subject to availability, from the Council’s Household Waste and Recycling Centres at Bossack in Tankerness, and Hatston, in Kirkwall.Collections fall on normal refuse recycling collection days and will take place as follows:Area  — Kirkwall : Monday February Area  — East Holm, Deerness, February Area  — Orphir and Stenness : Friday February Householders who wish to make use of the collection should ensure their Christmas trees are out at the normal collection point by am to guarantee pickup.Householders outwith the mph limits can visit their local Household Waste Recycling Centres at Hatston, Garson, Bossack, Cursiter Quarry, St Margaret’s Hope and Dounby during normal opening hours, where trees can be placed in the #green waste# skips.Opening hours are available on the council#s website, on the Civic Amenity Site page.Trees can also be trimmed, cut up and placed into the However, please noteusing this method they cannot be used as soil conditioner and will be shipped along with other waste collected.You can check which area your household falls into on the Your Household Collection — Mainland page of this website.For any enquiries, call the council’s Customer Service team on .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: featured property of the week 5
story: Offers over £,ADVERTORIAL: Westermill is an eye-catching period property located close to the centre of Kirkwall. The property is detached and comprises a large entrance hallway,  spacious bedrooms, one with ensuite, living room, dining room, kitchen, shower room, utility room and downstairs toilet. The property benefits from a large enclosed mature garden to the rear of the property and there are also a driveway and shed to the side of the house.The property has oil-fired central heating, together with a fireplace in the dining room and a Morso stove in the sitting room. There are also fireplaces in two of the bedrooms. Many of the original features have been retained in the property. Viewing is highly recommended to appreciate the true character of Westermill.The property is ideally located on a quiet road close to both the Papdale Primary and Kirkwall Grammar School and it is only a few minutes walk down to the centre of town. To the front of the property is the picturesque Willowburn, as well as additional parking.The living room has a hardwood floor, picture rail and cornice, as does the dining room. There is an archway leading from the dining room to the modern fitted kitchen with  ring hob, double oven, cooker hood, fridge and dishwasher.The ground floor also houses the utility room with plumbing for a washing machine and space for tumble dryer and fridge  freezer. There is a small toilet off the utility room. One of the bedrooms is situated on the ground floor, but could be used as a living room or office space.In the centre of the property is a beautul staircase leading up to a large stained glass feature window and then on to the landing. Off the landing there are a further three double bedrooms, one of which has an en-suite shower room. The main shower room is also located on the first floor of the property.There is a large loft space which is partially floored and could potentially be converted into a further one or two rooms, with ample space on the landing for a staircase.There is a walled garden to the front of the property, bordered with bushes and shrubs. The large rear garden has mature trees and bushes, making the garden area extremely sheltered and private. There is also a patio area and garden shed.Viewing is highly recommended to fully appreciate all that this property has to offer.The Home Report is available by email on request.For further information and to arrange a viewing, please contact Kerry Croy Tel:  . title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: update kirkwall town centre roadworks
story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. It#s anticipated this work will start on February  and could take four weeks to complete.The current one-way system means drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street but vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street.A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. This initial phase of the project is due for completion early May after which works will be suspended for the main summer season.Work at the entrance to Victoria Street is set to begin in the autumn, with a suspension planned, in December for Christmas shopping season.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. When the planning application is submitted, an opportunity will be given for representations to be made to the Planning Authority.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Bid for 60k funding as Dingwalls Puffin Pool limps along
story: AN urgent pound, fundraising campaign to enable essential repairs at an ailing hydrotherapy pool used by thousands of people suffering painful or disabling conditions has been launched.The charity-run Puffin Pool in Dingwall has been forced to close its doors on several occasions and is currently ldquolimping along, says its board which is urging people to support an appeal to keep it open.It provides specialist therapy to adults and children with conditions affecting their joints, bones, muscles or neurological system and is also used to help speed up rehabilitation after accidents and operations.But the pool has had to close several times due to the failure of the air handling unit.Board member Barbara Manson said it needed a major overhaul including a new ultra violet system for the water purication system and replacement entrance doors.ldquoIt is limping along until we can get new equipment, she said. ldquoItrsquos the fact the pool is  years old and everything is beginning to break down. We are also very aware there needs to be some internal structural alterations.Given the urgency, the board is using its capital reserves to order the new air handling unit which is should be installed in March.ldquoIf the equipment breaks down between now and then, the pool will have to close, Mrs Manson said. ldquoSome people attend the pool on a weekly basis and that is what keeps them going. If it has to close for a number of weeks, it can make a real dference to their mobility and pain control.Retired GP Helen Charley, board chairman, said:ldquoHaving been a GP in Cromarty for  years, and having needed both hips and knees replaced, I am all too aware of how vital the Puffin Pool is to the good health and wellbeing of so many patients like me, she said.Established in  by Dr Malcolm Stevens, the pool has provided an average , sessions each year over the past four years. They are supervised by qualied supervisors and leguards.The majority of income is from its charity shop In Tulloch Street and the fees which are kept affordable for those on benefits, pensions and low incomes although these have increased by  per cent.Supporters are rallying to support the appeal and staff plan a -mile sponsored walk from Tain to Dingwall.To donate, see www.puffinpool or pop in to the pool or shop.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Check your cold weather payment eligibility says Ross MP as temperature plummets
story: Local MP Ian Blackford sayspeople in the Ross, Skye and Lochaber constituency he serves should check eligibility with their nearest Job Centre Plus.This follows an alert of a triggering of the payment for postcode areas IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, between the period    to   .Cold weather payments are made from the Social Fund to certain recipients of Income Support, income-based Jobseekerrsquos Allowance, income-related Employment and Support Allowance, Universal Credit or Pension Credit during periods of very cold weather.To ldquotrigger the payments, the average temperature at a specied weather station must be recorded as, or forecast to be, degC or below for seven consecutive days.The scheme runs from November  to March  each year.The payment is a fixed amount for each week of cold weather. For many years this was set at pound. a week but the LabourGovernment increased the rate to pound a week as a temporary measure for winters - and -. In , the Coalition Government made the pound rate permanent.Payments should be made automatically to those entitled to them there should be no need to make a claim.However concerns have previously been raised that payments can be missed and Mr Blackford believes it is important that people, who believe that they may be eligible follow this through, particularly as the cold weather bites.He said: ldquoWe have been experiencing quite a prolonged period of cold and wet weather in the Highlands and Islands. It is hugely important that anyone eligible for a cold weather payment receives it. It can really make a dference to a vulnerable person or family who is experiencing high heating costs.ldquoThese payments should be made to eligible iniduals automatically, however, in my experience that is not always the case. I would urge anyone who believes that they may be due a payment to contact their nearest Job Centre Plus and get what they are owed.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Evanton project branches out with new building
story: COUPLES looking to tie the knot amidst naturersquos splendour will soon have a quirky new wedding venue to consider thanks to a major feat of engineering currently taking place within an Easter Ross woodland.The building currently under construction in Mags Wood near Evanton will also provide an ideal location for yoga sessions for those keen to get back to nature as well as ceilidhs and other community celebrations.Being carried out under the auspices of Evanton Community Woods, the building project may well result in the UKrsquos biggest freestanding reciprocal roofed structure, a simple, strong self-supporting technique perfect for round buildings.Simon Harry, education co-ordinator at Evanton Community Woods, explained how he had been aware of the need for another building within the woodland to provide the many groups already visiting the area more space within which to carry out their activities.He said: ldquoWe aim to run workshops such as green woodworking and outdoor learning from the space along as well as offering it to local groups such as guides and scouts to use for overnight expeditions.ldquoWe have also held a number of weddings in the woods and this would be a perfect location once completed.ldquoThe main driver for the project is that we are also training folk in the unique skills of log building, to share the skills. We have worked with local volunteers, school groups, young offenders, dementia groups, local walking groups and adult learners.In tune with the sustainable development ethos of the group, logs for Mags Wood build have been sourced locally and dragged to the site by Tarzan, a French-bred horse trained for forestry operations ndash and something of a visitor attraction in himself, hugely popular with the school groups who visit the site from time to time.The building project has been able to call on the expertise of local log building expert Henry Fosbrooke, project co-ordinator David Smith and a local volunteer, Don Fraser, who previously worked on the new Queensferry next to the Forth Road Bridge.Mr Harry said that such expertise ldquohas meant that all the measurements done are near perfect.The project has been funded by the Forestry Commission through a community grant amongst ious other sources.Mr Harry said: ldquoThis will be something special for the area and is involving many iniduals and groups in its building ndash truly a community project and something that will last a very, very long time.He is still hoping to find a supplier willing to help with the timber roof cladding required to complete the project, hopefully by the end of March. That would involve around  m x mm larch planks. The alternative will be to process locally sourced timber from the site.Anyone interested in becoming involved or who can help out can contact Simon Harry by email at simon.harry@forest-education or by calling  .Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Ex pat never forgot native Black Isle
story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a former Black Isle man who died at home after battling an illness for several years.Although he moved to Hannibal in Missouri in the s, Kenneth Macdonald, who was born in Fortrose in , retained a lasting interest in his home town, following events from afar through the hugely popular Fortrose and Rosemarkie Past and Present Facebook page.Mr Macdonald shared with that grouprsquos leading light, John Mackenzie, a great interest in motor sports and owned two lovely classic cars, a Triumph TR and a Corvette.Mr Mackenzie said he had decided to use the page to share news of the former Fortrose manrsquos death with others who might have known him. His father ran the family businesses, a coal merchant and a plasterers business in Fortrose.Mr Mackenzie said: ldquoKen ed to his home following a y stay in hospital.ldquoHe was delighted to sit in his own home and in his favourite chair and even smoked a cigarette. Irsquom sure that many of you will join me in offering our sincere condolences to his two daughters Mhairi and Katie and to their families.Mr Macdonaldrsquos late we, Susan, passed away in .During his early years in Fortrose, his budding talents emerged. He studied civil engineering at Edinburgh University and won a bursary to further his studies in the United States at Washington University in St Louis. It was in the States he met his we Susan whom he married in .Mr Macdonald also spent time during a distinguished engineering career in Benbecula during a period when the couple had moved to Edinburgh. There he was working with a contractor who in turn worked for the Ministry of Defence.His elder daughter Mhairi was born during the time they lived in Benbecula.After Benbecula the family moved to Hannibal where Mr Macdonald continued to work as an engineer.He was resident engineer with the Missouridepartment of transportationoverseeing the building of the Mark Twain Memorial Bridge across the Mississippi in the late s.Mr Macdonald continued toto Fortrose when possible but failing health over the past number of years meant that it was no longer possible.His passion for the place he grew up during his formative years was kindled by the local photographs posted on a regular basis on the Facebook page, ranging from present-day scenes to some more nostalgic images.He was also a member of the Hannibal Loafers car club.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Impressive turnout for Dingwalls new U3A group
story: THE inaugural meeting of a University of the Third Agegroup in Dingwall drew more than  people.The group brings allows people to learn with like-minded folk by creating interest groups and sharing skills and knowledge. It also organises monthly talks of general interest and provides a  for socialising and making contacts.Dingwall and District UA, part of a national movement, will host regular talks, the next of which is on Thursday, February  in The Baptist Church Hall, Tulloch Street, Dingwall at pm.It will be addressed by bridge builder Don Fraser MBE whose last project was construction of the Queensferry Crossing.The organisation has proved a hit in particular with retired people interest in learning new things in their own time with like-minded folk. Interest groups can have as few as two people in them.Last weekrsquos meeting in Dingwall was addressed by Ed Link, Third Age Trustee for Scotland and Linda Clark, Third Age Trust Volunteer.The group has a web site at https:uasites.org.uk dingwall home and a presence on Facebook.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: New homes planned for Dingwall
story: DINGWALL moved a step closer to getting  new homes after the Ross and Cromarty area committee agreed an infrastructure investment ldquounlocking the possibility of the development.But councillors were at odds over the plans with some considering them a sop in lieu of the  homes earmarked for the town since  while others said it was a ldquopositive move in a high pressure area for housing demand.The original plan was based on the delivery of the Kinnairdie Link Roadproject ndash expected to unleash millions in inward investment. It was due to start its final phase of construction this year but it was axed from the councilrsquos capital programme in last yearrsquos budget.Then in March, funding for transport improvements in Dingwall was found to enable some housing development to take place prior to the commencement of the KLR.A transport study and modelling work considered the impact of ious levels of development in the town and improvements will include work at the Bridgend Avenue Junction and Docharty Road Junction as well as traffic signal works at Mart Road Junction. Proposals for walking and cycling improvements and traffic management measures will also be brought forward to enhance active travel facilities in the town.Dingwall and Seaforth councillor Graham Mackenzie said: ldquoIt would be tempting to see it as a good news story for Dingwall. That is not the case. Had we been given what we were promised in an earlier iteration of the capital plan we could be releasing up to  houses for development instead of around ."Instead the KLR was taken out of the capital plan even though the first phase of the project had already started. If Dingwall is to grow and provide the range of housing which is required, the KLR must be moved up the list of priorities. This project needs to be reinstated.Fellow ward councillor Angela Maclean insisted the deal was good news. She said: ldquoWe as councillors have a leadership role and it is up to us to be helping our communities to move forward and this report has examples of when officers have looked for solutions to get round some of the fact that we donrsquot have all the money we would like."Whether it is through the infrastructure road plans or capital fund we are going to try and move forward with these houses in Dingwall, because Dingwall is a pressurised area ndash this is a positive move because we donrsquot have enough houses in Dingwall.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Old office goes back on market in Dingwall
story: The former assessorrsquos office in Ferry Road, which adjoins the old Sherf Court, dates back to .A category B listed commercial property it was on the market a year ago and it was thought a buyer had been found. But the sale fell through and the property is again up for sale with offers over pound, invited.Originally built as a police station, the property has a colourful history with its location next to the courthouse.The sherf court was closed by the Scottish Court Service in January  as part of a cost-cutting and restructuring scheme.The following year the property was sold and converted into a private dwelling. The former police station been used for many years by Highland Council as offices for the assessor.The assessor is responsible for assigning a value to properties for tax purposes.Because it was a commercial property it is not necessary to provide a survey of the building to potential buyers.It is in a mix of modern and traditional residential properties close to the town centre on Ferry Road.Of stone and slate construction it comprises three rooms on the ground floor and four rooms on the first floor.A council spokesman said the property requires extensive work, but it has its own entrance and parking to the front of the property.The closing date set for offers is March , .Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Tain hub and Picture House project progress to come under spotlight
story: Tain and District Development Trusthas already been successful in raising well over pound, towards its projects and secured three employed positions for the local area.On Thursday, February the group is staging a community consultation in the towns Duthac Centre at pm.TDDTs Sarah Mackenzie said: "Weve worked hard to gain a closer relationship with local businesses and groups within Tain and district in order to increase our social and economic impact to the local area making us more attractive to potential funders and investors."To date we have bid and successfully received funding for ourselves and partner projects from FirstPort, Highlands and Islands Enterprise, SSE Beatrice Wind Farm, Beinn Tharsuinn Wind farm Trust and Highland Council."With these funds we are now in a position to employ a community fund manager, business development manager and an administrator to help take our projects to the next level and increase our community-wide benefit. We hope to have these positions filled by early spring."The funds will also allowTDDT to fit out its new community enterprise hub on Stafford Street inTain.Said Ms Mackenzie: "The hub will be the cornerstone to all of our projects as well as providing a space that caters to the wider community offering conferencing facilities, meeting rooms, hot desking andpop-up phops. We hope to be open for business in March this year."Highlands and Islands Enterpriseis providing funding support towards the cost of developing the hub and recruiting a manager.Stewart Wardlaw, HIE Development Manager, Inner Moray Firth area, said: "The Hub will provide valuable business services locally, for commercial and social enterprises."It will also help facilitate the use of business premises within the local community and in a town centre location. This will help make the Tain district a more attractive option for businesses and drive growth locally."We are very pleased to be able to provide support and look forward to seeing the project develop.Through the SSE Beatrice Wind Farm Fund, TDDThas received funds to cover the costs for a full business plan and feasibility study towards the Picture House project.Along with Tain Heritage Trust and Tain and Easter Ross Civic Trust,TDDT hasalready managed to successfully clear the outside of the premises andtidy up inside,allowing the community a rare glimpse of a building through photographs thatmany hold close to their hearts.The Beatrice Partnership Fund said it wasdelighted to support the community withits aspirations to restorethe iconic local building.Tain Heritage Trusts Chairman David Robertson welcomed the support theyve had in recent months from Tain  Easter Ross Civic Trust and from Tain  District Development Trust to help kick-start the Picture House redevelopment.He said: "This help has now secured us funding for a feasibilitystudy from SSE.We welcome the involvement of SSE in what really would be a transformational project for the town."Lets hope this is the start of a fruitful partnership with them to secure the phased restoration of our Royal Burghs much-loved hall. Our town can only prosper when groups work together for the CommonWeal. Thats what we are seeing with the Development Trust. Long may it continue."Tain and Easter Ross Civic Trust says it is proud to be playing a signicant role in the restoration of this building dating from  it is one of the finest works of the Maitland firm of architects who designed so many of the Victorian and Edwardian buildings that form such an important part of Tains heritage.Hamish Mackenzie of the Trust said: "It played a major role in the le of Tain, first as a public hall and then from  s as a cinema and we hope to see it resuming to its former glory in the st century."The community consultation on Thursday in the Duthac Centre at pm will give people a chance to see the development made so far as well as having their say on future developments.Member votes will required to make amendments to our constitution in order to progress the Picture House Project and to secure larger funds and investments.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: devolution cannot stand in the way of human rights christine jardine
story: The UK Supreme Court and the United Nations have both warned that domestic abuse laws in Northern Ireland are undermining women#s human rights, but the UK Government is refusing to act even though the Stormont government is not currently sitting, writes Christine Jardine.Abuse comes dressed up in a iety of disguises.In some forms, it can appear warm and loving, even perhaps vulnerable, to the casual observer. But all are nasty, evil and damaging to those on the receiving end.At its worst, abuse can undermine the human rights of the people – usually, but not exclusively, women – who are subjected to it.One of the worst forms of domestic violence is sexual.Here in the UK we tend to think that we are alert to the dangers.As a society we believe that we abhor, and fight at every opportunity, to expose and excise abuse, of every iation.But just recently we were given a stark rebuke. Two in fact.Both the UK Supreme Court and the United Nations warned that the current domestic abuse laws in Northern Ireland are undermining the human rights of its women. That women in this part of our country do not have the benefit of the same rights and protection of the law as the rest of us.If that was not bad enough,any of us, or our daughters, should move to that other part of the UK we would lose the rights we were born with. You maybe wonder how, or even doubt, this is possible. But it is.The UK Supreme Court concluded that Northern Ireland’s abortion law is incompatible with human rights.: Nicola Sturgeon urged to back efforts to legalise abortion in Northern IrelandThe United Nations stated that the UK is violating the rights of women in Northern Ireland by restricting their access to abortion.To be clear, this is not an argument about the rights and wrongs of abortion, but of human rights. It is about whether people in every part of the UK enjoy the same basic rights.Before Parliament at the moment is an opportunity to address that inequality. But so far it remains untaken.And more often than not the excuse given is one that I find particularly hard to swallow: devolution.In each of the debates that I have been part of on this issue, the fact of the legislative existence of Stormont has been used as an excuse.The argument regularly made – and one I would normally agree with – is that devolved areas should not be interfered with.In this case, however, I am often left incredulous by those who say that while they recognise the situation is unacceptable and the law is in need of reform we shouldn’t interfere, even though Northern Ireland does not, at the moment have a working devolved legislature.That offends my sense of justice.When they have been asked, the majority of people in Northern Ireland have agreed that Westminster should step in.: Jacob Rees-Mogg: Easing NI abortion law would ‘damage the Union’Surely the people of Northern Ireland have a right to expect the same human rights as their fellow citizens in every other part of the UK I would expect no less for any of us in Scotland, although I am sure that we would never need that redress and certainly in this area the law in Scotland is already enacted.To be clear this is not, for me, simply about this Domestic Abuse Bill.Yes, Northern Ireland has the most restrictive abortion law in Europe with a near blanket ban, even for cases where there is a medical reason. And that is certainly central to the argument.This week Belfast high Court began hearing the case of a woman, Sarah Ewart, who was denied an abortion even though she was told her unborn baby had a fatal condition. She was forced to borrow money to make the journey to the UK for an abortion.Since , more than , women and girls have travelled to another country for an abortion. In , , made that traumatic journey.Sarah Ewart has the support of Northern Ireland’s human rights commission and of MPs like myself who last year voted to force Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley to explain how officials can continue to enforce the ban.However, in Parliament, this has become about which should be more important: a constitutional argument or the human rights of the population.For me the people, not the constitution or national identity, should come first.Devolution, as I argued in the Commons, means that areas of legislation are delegated, or transferred to another authority.It should not mean that the UK Government abrogates all responsibility for the welfare of UK citizens or that it should not step up to resolve an injustice that is being done to some or any of our people, when there is no other body to fight their corner.And neither should those of us in areas with devolved authorities use it as a defence against helping others. Indeed, not only has the UN argued that is the case, two-thirds of adults in Northern Ireland have agreed that, without their own devolved government, Westminster should act to change the law.In parliament this week I felt for Conservative minister Victoria Atkins MP, a barrister in her former career, who had to make the Government’s argument that women in Northern Ireland could not have the protection of the Domestic Abuse Bill currently going through parliament because it is a devolved area.Ms Atkins obviously feels as passionately as any of us that domestic abuse must be tackled but could not accept the case that it should be extended to Northern Ireland in the absence of a working executive there. There is currently a private members’ bill going through parliament, which I have backed, aimed at tackling the same issue.And there have been several recent attempts to change the law over what should and, in a better world, would be the private healthcare concern of the inidual women concerned.For the moment at least, it seems that those who fail to overcome the roadblocks to re-establishing devolution in Northern Ireland also fail to protect the rights of its women.Surely it’s time the rest of us took responsibility.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: john swinney was opposed to workplace parking plan
story: The Scottish Government is facing growing pressure to spell out how a controversial new charging regime for Scots to park at work will operate.It has emerged that senior SNP figures, including Deputy First Minister John Swinney, have previously opposed such a proposal.The Tories now say the scheme could "fall apart" before it has even begun.Read more: The SNP’s Car Tax is a Poll Tax on wheels - Brian MonteithThe workplace parking levy was among a suite of new taxes unveiled last week as a part of a budget deal with the Scottish Greens.But its has prompted a backlash among business leaders and motoring organisations with concerns that commuters could now be charged as much as £ a year to park at work.NHS staff will be exempt, but it remains unclearteachers will be excluded or whether it applies to blue-badge holders and emergency service workers. There is also no indicationsmall businesses will be supported.,There are also concerns about the impact on rural areas where people often have no choice but to drive to work.Read more: Parking levy in Scotland ‘could force teachers to quit the profession’Tory finance spokesman Murdo Fraser saidministers can’t offer urgent clarication on the levy, they should drop it altogether.“It’s blatantly title: key snp figures told by nicola sturgeon to prepare for possible election
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...SNP parliamentarians have been told by Nicola Sturgeon to prepare for a possible Scottish electionthe government at Holyrood fails to pass its budget today.The Scottish Government heads into today’s vote without a deal to secure a majority, risking defeat on its spending plans for the coming year.During a meeting of the SNP group at Westminster attended by the First Minister on Monday, Ms Sturgeon warned her MPs that they should prepare for a possible Scottish election campaignthe government fails to get its budget through, The Scotsman understands.However the move comes amid speculation that Ms Sturgeon may need a fresh mandate from the electorate to secure another referendum on independence, as she prepares to reveal her plans on the issue. Publicly, the government has stated that it is focused on getting its spending plans passed and is confident of reaching a compromise.In , when an SNP minority government had its budget defeated by the Scottish Parliament, then-First Minister Alex Salmond threatened a snap election before the deadlock was broken.The current SNP minority has struck a more conciliatory tone and sought to calm speculation about an election, with Finance Secretary Derek Mackay last night appealing for MSPs to “act responsibly”.Last ditch talks are set to continue today in the final hours before a vote, with the Green Party holding out for concessions on local government spending and council tax reform.Mr Mackay must secure the support of the six Green MSPs to pass his budget, with all other opposition parties committed to voting against it.Green Party co-convener Patrick Harvie has dismissed suggestions his party could bring down the government by rejecting the SNP’s budget as a “myth”.But senior Nationalist figures were openly speculating about the possibility of an election earlier in the week, with SNP committee convener Gillian Martin warning Green MSP Andy Wightman on social media that voting down the budget could force an election and put a second Scottish independence referendum at risk.“You’ve seen the way the other parties coalesce against us to try and bring down the government,” Ms Martin posted on Twitter. “Since  everything for them is about defeating the pro-Indy Parliament.”She added: “We are at risk of an election that might see pro Indy parties lose seats and put us in a weaker position.”Polls show the SNP remains in the lead in Scottish Parliament voting intention, but that the nationalists have lost ground compared with their performance in the  Holyrood election where they narrowly lost their majority.Scottish Conservative shadow finance secretary Murdo Fraser claimed uncertainty around the budget showed the SNP were “unfit” for government.“The SNP has neglected the day job so badly that it’s now struggling to get the single-biggest responsibility taken care of. Nicola Sturgeon is so resigned to the weakness of her own administration, she’s been forced to rally the troops for another election.“Hers would be the first government in the history of the Scottish Parliament to call an election because it couldn’t pass a budget.“That would be a shameful legacy, and shows just how unfit the Nationalists are for government of any kind.”Scottish Liberal Democrat campaign chair Alex Cole-Hamilton MSP said: “We’ve made clear to the SNP that we want a budget that focuses on education, mental health and local government funding.“If their inability to get a budget through necessitates a new Scottish Parliament election then I have every hope that people in Scotland will want to use that to eject the Nationalists.”A Labour spokesman said “no credible anti-austerity party would propose” the draft budget put forward by the SNP.With no deal last night, Mr Mackay said: “Our spending plans for the coming year contain additional money for schools and hospitals, protecting vital public services and investing in our economy, while also providing stability amid the ongoing uncertainty caused by Brexit. “With that backdrop in mind, there has never been more need for MSPs, of all parties, to act responsibly and not add to that uncertainty.”Mr Mackay added: “We are open to compromise in order to ensure we deliver the Budget that the country expects.” ©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: nicola sturgeon uk not remotely prepared for brexit
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...The UK is #not remotely prepared# for Brexit and the process must be delayed, Nicola Sturgeon will warn in a keynote speech in the US today.The First Minister will step up calls for a second referendum with just  days left until the UK is due to formally leave the European Union.Prime Minister Theresa May insisted yesterday that Brexit will happen “on time” as she prepared toto Brussels seeking changes to the Irish backstop, a sticking point of her EU Withdrawal Deal which has been rejected by the Commons.But she faced a warning from the Irish deputy prime minister that “there are no credible alternative arrangements” to the proposal.She was also stung by the announcement that Japanese car giant Nissan has axed plans to make its X-Trail x vehicle in Sunderland, citing several reasons including Brexit uncertainty.Ms Sturgeon will launch a broadside at the turmoil engulfing Westminster over Brexit and insist that Scotland’s interests have been treated as an “afterthought” in a speech in Washington, DC today.“The UK is not remotely prepared to leave the EU in  days’ time,” Ms Sturgeon will say. “The UK government should finally recognise that, and it should ask the EU to agree to put back the planned date for Brexit.”Such a request would have to be backed up by an “achievable plan”, with Ms Sturgeon suggesting the UK government could reconsider plans to leave the single market and customs union. She will tell her audience at Georgetown University that a “better option is to hold a further referendum on EU membership”. “The Scottish Government’s view is that this issue should be put back to the people,” the First Minister will say on the first day of a trade mission to the US and Canada.“That no Scottish Parliament, of any political composition, would approach Brexit in the way that the UK government has helps to explain why Brexit is also relevant to the debate on Scottish independence.“In the independence referendum in , voters in Scotland were repeatedly told thatwe became independent, we would have to leave the European Union. Voting to stay in the UK was portrayed as the way to protect our EU membership. That in itself raises the question of whether decisions about Scotland should continue to be taken at Westminster or whether it would be betterthey were taken in Scotland. And now the ongoing chaos at Westminster and the way Scotland’s interests have been consistently ignored makes that question even more relevant. “So I have said I will outline my thoughts on the timing of a possible independence referendum in the next few weeks, once the terms of Brexit are clearer. But, amid the chaos, confusion and uncertainty of Brexit, one thing is clearer than ever. Namely, that Scotland’s vital national interests are not properly served by relying on the Westminster system which treats Scotland as an afterthought, and that those interests can only properly be served by being an independent country.”But writing in a weekend newspaper article, Mrs May insisted the departure date will not change and that she would “deliver Brexit on time”.The EU Withdrawal Agreement she struck with Brussels was rejected by the Commons over the Irish backstop provision which is aimed at keeping the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic open after Brexit.She said: “When Ito Brussels … I will be armed with a fresh mandate, new ideas and a renewed determination to agree a pragmatic solution that delivers the Brexit the British people voted for, while ensuring there is no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.”Last week Mrs May secured Parliament’s backing to go back to Brussels in the hope of hammering out a fresh agreement that does not include the backstop – which is unacceptable to the DUP and Brexiteer Tories – and which will command a Commons majority.The Prime Minister is due to report back to Parliament on  February, with a further series of votes by MPs expected the following day.However, there was a was warning for Mrs May that she may be opposed by her own Eurosceptic backbenchersthe deal she gets falls short of their expectations.European Research Group deputy chairman Steve Baker tweeted that there could be “trouble ahead” and suggested changes to the backstop may not satisfy them. “Leave-backing MPs voted to support alternative arrangements in NI [Northern Ireland] but with grave misgivings about the whole agreement,” he wrote.It came as a senior Nissan boss blasted Brexit “uncertainty” as he confirmed the company had scrapped plans to build the X-Trail x at its Sunderland plant.Gianluca de Ficchy, the Japanese firm’s Europe chairman, said the decision had been taken for “business reasons” affected by rules on diesel engines and reduced sales.The announcement that the X-Trail would be built in Japan was made in a letter to staff that followed a day of political rows between Brexit supporters and opponents over the reason for one of Wearside’s largest employers going against a  decision to build the car there.In the letter, Mr de Ficchy also said: “Clearly the uncertainty around the UK’s future relationship with the EU is not helping companies like ours to plan for the future.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: poll half of voters back delaying brexit to negotiate new deal
story: Almost half of voterswould back delaying Brexit beyond the scheduled date of March  to allow time to negotiate a better deal, according to a new poll.With just  days remaining to the UK’s withdrawal from the EU, just % said they would oppose a delay for this purpose.Those questioned for the monthly YouGov tracker poll for The Times also backed postponing Brexit to give more time to make preparations for a no-deal departure, by a margin of %-%.But they opposed a delay to hold a general election by %-% or a second referendum by %-% and were almost evenly spliton whether the Government should seek more time to get Theresa May’s Withdrawal Agreement through.Some % of those questioned said that MPs were right to back the so-called Brady Amendment, offering Parliament’s support for the agreement so long as the controversial backstop arrangement for the Irish border is removed. - Man admits chopping up body of vulnerable granBut % said it was wrong and - in a sign of public uncertainty on the issue - % said they did not know.Just % thought it likely that the EU would agree to ditch the backstop, against % who said it would not.Only % said that the Government had done a good job of negotiating with the EU, compared with % who said it had done a bad job.And just % of those questioned thought Mrs May’s deal would be good for the country, against % who saw it as a bad outcome.More than halfsaid that leaving without a deal would be bad for the country, compared with just % who thought it would be a good outcome.Some % of the , voters questioned said the UK had made the wrong decision when it opted to leave the EU in the  referendum, against % who thought it was right to leave. - William Wallace story to be told ‘better than ever’When don’t knows were removed, the result was Wrong %, Right %.It is now more than a year since the monthly poll recorded a majority thinking that the  referendum result was the right thing for Britain.Some % said that a new referendum resulting in the UK remaining in the EU would be a good outcome for Britain and % viewed it as an “acceptable compromise”.But % said this would be bad - including % who said it would be very bad - for the country.More than halfsaid that a second referendum with a Remain victory would make the country more ided, against just % who said it would bring Britain together.A Norway-style Brexit leaving the UK in the single market and customs union was regarded as a good result by % and bad by %.Less than one in eightof those questioned said that Labour’s policy on Europe was “clear”, compared with % who said it was “confusing”.And just % said they supported Jeremy Corbyn’s approach to Brexit, against % who oppose it.When the same question was asked about the Conservative policy, some % found it clear and % confusing.Mrs May’s approach was backed by % and opposed by %.- YouGov questioned , British adults on January  and .©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: snp and greens agree on a new budget deal for councils
story: Shetland Islands Council should benefit from an extra £. million from the Scottish government, according to Green MSP for the Highlands and Islands John Finnie.Mr Finnie#s party is heralding a Holyrood agreement on what is described as #a signicant package of immediate budget changes# to boost council funding.The party says it has gained support from Scottish ministers ahead of the Stage  vote on the budget which is due to take place on Thursday evening.Ministers are promising to amend their spending plans infor Green support.The Greens say that, compared with the plans set out in the SNP#s budget in December, councils will have access to a package worth over £ million to spend as they see fit.Ministers have also agreed to a timescale for replacing the council tax system.This will be developed by a cross-party process starting before the summer. Legislation is due to be published before the end of this session of parliament.Council bosses have previously described the SNP government#s proposed budget for   as bad news, putting at risk the delivery of essential services.Mr Finnie said: #The public rely on local services such as schools and social care, and local facilities such as sports centres and libraries. Today#s Green budget deal means that Shetland Islands Council now has an additional £. million to protect these services and the jobs of front line workers.#It#s welcome that after consistent Green pressure the SNP government has seen sense and committed to immediate action and longer-term reform.#Scottish Greens will always be firm but constructive in these situations.
